rows.text: This family contains some of the largest transporters (over 2,100 amino acids long). Five of them are located in a cluster in the 17q24 chromosome.
Responsible for the transportation of cholesterol and lipids, among other things.
Consists of 4 full and 7 half transporters.
Some are located in the blood–brain barrier, liver, mitochondria, transports peptides and bile, for example.
Used in ion transport, cell-surface receptors, toxin secretion. Includes the CFTR protein, which causes cystic fibrosis when deficient.
Consists of 1 ABCE and 3 ABCF proteins.

These are not actually transporters but merely ATP-binding domains that were derived from the ABC family, but without the transmembrane domains. These proteins mainly regulate protein synthesis or expression.
Consists of 6 "reverse" half-transporters, with the NBF at the NH3+ end and the TM at the COO- end.
Transports lipids, diverse drug substrates, bile, cholesterol, and other steroids.
